document_metadata.name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: It can present with changes in sensation, mobility, balance, sphincter function, vision, and cognition.

links.evidence: It can present with changes in sensation, mobility, balance, sphincter function, vision, and cognition.

links.evidence: It can present with changes in sensation, mobility, balance, sphincter function, vision, and cognition.

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: CSF findings include a normal or mildly raised white cell count (<25 cells per cm³; predominantly lymphocytes) and protein (usually <1 g/L), a raised IgG index, and IgG oligoclonal bands not present in serum.14

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: CSF findings include a normal or mildly raised white cell count (<25 cells per cm³; predominantly lymphocytes) and protein (usually <1 g/L), a raised IgG index, and IgG oligoclonal bands not present in serum.14

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: CSF findings include a normal or mildly raised white cell count (<25 cells per cm³; predominantly lymphocytes) and protein (usually <1 g/L), a raised IgG index, and IgG oligoclonal bands not present in serum.14

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Younger age, male sex, and gadolinium enhancing, cortical, or spinal cord lesions might be associated with an increased risk of developing multiple sclerosis.29–31

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: A diagnosis of multiple sclerosis should only be made in a patient who has symptoms suggestive of demyelination.[2]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: In younger children (<12 years of age) multiple sclerosis can present differently from in adolescents and adults; encephalopathy, multifocal neurological deficits (often with prominent brainstem or cerebellar involvement), and seizures are more common.[32]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: In younger children (<12 years of age) multiple sclerosis can present differently from in adolescents and adults; encephalopathy, multifocal neurological deficits (often with prominent brainstem or cerebellar involvement), and seizures are more common.[32]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: In younger children (<12 years of age) multiple sclerosis can present differently from in adolescents and adults; encephalopathy, multifocal neurological deficits (often with prominent brainstem or cerebellar involvement), and seizures are more common.[32]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: These disorders include several closely related idiopathic inflammatory CNS diseases (tables 1, 2), along with a range of other disorders that can involve white matter (eg, inherited leukodystrophies, vasculopathies, and metabolic disorders), and other neuroinflammatory diseases (eg, sarcoidosis, vasculitis, and Behcet’s disease).

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: The clinical, imaging, and laboratory features of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis and multiple sclerosis overlap and diagnostic criteria emphasise the requirement of encephalopathy (altered level of consciousness, behavioural, or cognitive change) in making the diagnosis of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (appendix). [32]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: People with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis may develop a progressive course with time (secondary progressive multiple sclerosis) with a gradual increase in disability with or without relapses.[2]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Panel 1 shows some common presenting symptoms and signs of multiple sclerosis and selected others that are less common and suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: A first episode of neurological dysfunction, presumably due to relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis, is called a clinically isolated syndrome.[2,5]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: People with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis may develop a progressive course with time (secondary progressive multiple sclerosis) with a gradual increase in disability with or without relapses.[2]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Diagnosis is based on the presence of clinical symptoms and signs and findings on MRI, which is highly sensitive to detect characteristic CNS lesions.1

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Cortical grey matter is frequently involved in multiple sclerosis pathologically, but cortical lesions are rarely visualised on conventional MRI sequences and are better seen using double inversion recovery (DIR) or phase-sensitive inversion recovery (PSIR) techniques.73,75

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: A major discovery was the association between neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder and serum aquaporin 4 IgG (AQP4-IgG), confirming that it is a different disease from multiple sclerosis and needs distinct treatment.[4]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: MRI in patients with small vessel cerebrovascular disease, other inflammatory disorders, and non-inflammatory disorders affecting white matter (tables 1, 2), and even in healthy people (especially in older age groups), might show brain lesions that fulfil MRI criteria for multiple sclerosis.[21–24]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: The core clinical features of neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder are optic neuritis and transverse myelitis.

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: MRI in patients with small vessel cerebrovascular disease, other inflammatory disorders, and non-inflammatory disorders affecting white matter (tables 1, 2), and even in healthy people (especially in older age groups), might show brain lesions that fulfil MRI criteria for multiple sclerosis.[21–24]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: The core clinical features of neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder are optic neuritis and transverse myelitis.

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: MRI in patients with small vessel cerebrovascular disease, other inflammatory disorders, and non-inflammatory disorders affecting white matter (tables 1, 2), and even in healthy people (especially in older age groups), might show brain lesions that fulfil MRI criteria for multiple sclerosis.[21–24]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder is an inflammatory astrocytopathy of the CNS with clinical and radiological features that overlap with multiple sclerosis. [4]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Characteristic lesions are those extending over more than half the length of the optic nerve, and sometimes into the optic chiasm. [49,50]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: About 70% of patients with relapsing neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder are AQP4-IgG-positive, with the sensitivity increased with the use of cell-based rather than ELISA assays.[53,54]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: A major discovery was the association between neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder and serum aquaporin 4 IgG (AQP4-IgG), confirming that it is a different disease from multiple sclerosis and needs distinct treatment.[4]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Panel 1 shows some common presenting symptoms and signs of multiple sclerosis and selected others that are less common and suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Common clinically isolated syndrome presentations include acute unilateral optic neuritis, a partial myelitis, or a brainstem syndrome.[5]

links.evidence: Common clinically isolated syndrome presentations include acute unilateral optic neuritis, a partial myelitis, or a brainstem syndrome.[5]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: The onset of primary progressive multiple sclerosis by contrast is characterised by slowly progressive symptoms, most often an asymmetric paraparesis that evolves over months or years,6 or, less commonly, a progressive hemiparesis or cerebellar ataxia or very rarely, visual failure or dementia.[6]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: The onset of primary progressive multiple sclerosis by contrast is characterised by slowly progressive symptoms, most often an asymmetric paraparesis that evolves over months or years,6 or, less commonly, a progressive hemiparesis or cerebellar ataxia or very rarely, visual failure or dementia.[6]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: The McDonald criteria provide separate recommendations for the diagnosis of primary progressive multiple sclerosis, which includes testing for CSF abnormalities in addition to MRI.[1]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Oligoclonal bands can sometimes be present in patients with other neuroinflammatory disorders and their presence needs to be interpreted carefully.

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Younger age, male sex, and gadolinium enhancing, cortical, or spinal cord lesions might be associated with an increased risk of developing multiple sclerosis.29–31

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: However, spinal cord lesions can be very helpful in making a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (cord lesions do not occur with healthy ageing or cerebrovascular disease [11] and provide additional evidence of dissemination in space [10]) and might provide important prognostic information.[67]

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis is an inflammatory demyelinating disorder of the CNS, distinct from multiple sclerosis, that occurs mainly in children and is rare in adults

citation.db_name: Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis: progress and challenges.

links.evidence: CSF findings include a lymphocytic pleocytosis and raised protein.

links.evidence: The clinical, imaging, and laboratory features of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis and multiple sclerosis overlap and diagnostic criteria emphasise the requirement of encephalopathy (altered level of consciousness, behavioural, or cognitive change) in making the diagnosis of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (appendix). [32]
